results.body: With no luck at all, the Spaniards and then the French long searched for oil in the waters around this tiny nation, half of which sits on the Central African mainland and half on an island in the Atlantic. Then suddenly in 1996, after Spanish and French oilmen had left, the Americans struck liquid gold. The discovery was so unexpected that the
results.title: Oil Riches, and Risks, in Tiny African Nation

results.title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

Bush of Texas spent $13.1 million in February, more than half of it on television and radio advertisements in the crucial primary contests that helped him become the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, the Bush campaign said yesterday. By the end of February, Mr. Bush had spent a
results.title: Campaign Briefing

results.body: There was a time when if Blair Hull, a former blackjack player and options trader, said he was prepared to spend $40 million of his own fortune to win his first political job -- a seat in the United States Senate -- his deep pockets might have scared opponents out of the race. But not this year. Now candidates facing rich opponents can use a
results.title: In Races With One Deep Pocket, The Law Tries to Tailor a Second

results.body: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich said today that he would continue his predecessor's moratorium on executions and would not automatically lift it even if the General Assembly sent him a package of bills intended to eliminate wrongful convictions. Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, said there was no single improvement that would persuade him to lift the
results.title: Illinois Keeps A Moratorium On Executions

results.body: Peter Fitzgerald, the Republican banking heir who spent $13 million in 1998 to become the youngest member of the United States Senate, announced this afternoon that he would not seek a second term, throwing open a critical contest that could determine the balance of power in the Senate. Mr. Fitzgerald, 42, a maverick whose independent votes have
results.title: Illinois Senator Announces He Won't Seek Re-election

results.title: Jesse Jackson, a Club Owner and Lasting Ties

results.body: John Kerry returned to the Senate on Tuesday for the first time since the election and spent much of the day there the same way he has spent much of the last 20 years -- on his own. He kept his counsel, meeting with aides and making phone calls in the private Capitol office that his staff shied from calling by its usual but newly poignant nickname:
results.title: Kerry Returns to Capitol, For the Most Part Silent

results.body: FAREWELL to Swift boats and ''Shove it!,'' to Osama's tape and Saddam's missing weapons, to ''security moms'' and outsourced dads. They've all been sent to history's dustbin faster than Ralph Nader memorabilia was dumped on eBay. In their stead stands a single ambiguous phrase coined by an anonymous exit pollster: ''Moral values.'' By near
results.title: On 'Moral Values,' It's Blue in A Landslide

results.body: Hardly anybody likes the current tax system. But as President Bush undertakes the potentially historic task of coming up with something better, he is confronting an issue that is more ideologically explosive, politically risky and economically complex than he let on during the campaign. In the days since his re-election, Mr. Bush has signaled that
results.title: Big Tax Plans, Big Tax Risks

results.body: Turning Angel By Greg Iles 501 pages. Scribner. $25.95. You can tell a lot about a murder mystery from its corpse. In ''Turning Angel,'' the significantly deceased is Kate Townsend, a beautiful Harvard-bound high school senior. Kate was Natchez, Miss.'s most virtuous 17-year-old girl until this book starts digging up perverse details. Then things
results.title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Rampaging Adolescence Down Mississippi Way

results.body: JERI RYAN did not want the details of her divorce made public. But when a court ordered the documents unsealed, they revealed that she had accused her ex-husband, Jack Ryan, then the Republican Senate candidate from Illinois, of repeatedly asking her to go to sex clubs and to have sex in public, telling her when she cried that tears were a turnoff.
results.byline: By KATE ZERNIKE; Research for this article was contributed by Sandra Jamison.
results.title: THE NATION; What Some Politicians Fear Most: The Ex-Wife

results.body: In the first political races of the Republic, virtually every candidate paid his own way -- from handbills and newspaper ads to wining and dining other landowners. Fund-raising was scarce. The campaign staff might have been a horse. But personal wealth did not guarantee victory. As the story goes, a young George Washington lost a seat in the
results.title: Pity the Rich In Politics: They Tend To Fare Poorly

results.body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg campaigned for 17 hours yesterday as he hit each borough twice in search of a historic victory -- and an overwhelming new mandate -- at the polls on Election Day. His Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer, concentrated on avoiding an embarrassing defeat, especially with black voters, by making clear that he had not given
results.byline: By PATRICK D. HEALY; Thomas J. Lueck and Mike McIntire contributed reporting for this article.
results.title: THE 2005 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK CITY; What Polls? Mayoral Rivals Run Right to the End

results.body: Even by the bare-knuckled standards of national political campaigns, the contentious race for New Jersey governor between two multimillionaires, United States Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester, has been particularly venomous. Last week, Mr. Forrester quoted Mr. Corzine's ex-wife in an ad attacking the senator's integrity. Mr. Corzine
results.byline: By RICHARD LEZIN JONES; Josh Benson and John Holl contributed reporting for this article.
results.title: In New Jersey, Smiley Sunday Near End of a Mean Campaign

Bloomberg and his Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer, charged through the five boroughs yesterday urging their supporters to vote in large numbers as their campaigns clashed over Mr. Bloomberg's spending. With the race in its final weekend, both men beseeched followers to cast their votes on Tuesday regardless of polls showing
results.byline: By JIM RUTENBERG and DIANE CARDWELL; Winnie Hu contributed reporting for this article.

After all, Mr. Jindal devoted nearly all of his remarks to how his immigrant parents were his heroes. Not until the last minute of his speech did
results.title: ON POLITICS; A Governor's Race, And a Dress Rehearsal

results.body: It seems only fitting that Senator Jon S. Corzine's career in politics was set in motion by a bold idea that cost him dearly. In August 1998, Mr. Corzine, already wealthy and running one of the world's most profitable investment banks, was straining at his leash. He had been helping to orchestrate the bailout of a huge investment fund that was
results.byline: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI and PATRICK McGEEHAN
results.title: THE RACE FOR TRENTON: The Democrat; Corzine's Mix: Bold Ambitions But Rough Edges

results.body: The body of Rosa Parks lay in the Capitol Rotunda this morning, on view for thousands of Americans who wanted to honor the woman known as the mother of the civil rights movement. Her death last week has created a moment, many African-Americans engaged in political struggle say, to take stock of what that movement accomplished and whether it is
results.title: Grieving Rosa Parks, Rights Leaders Ponder Future and Seek New Focus and Methods

results.title: Michael Brown, Redux

results.body: THE campaign for president will dominate American politics in the coming year, and while Republicans and Democrats will no doubt be talking about very different things, they face a common strategic challenge: How do you deal with the folks back in Washington? For Republican candidates, the problem is President Bush. They are in a different place
results.title: THE YEAR AHEAD: POLITICS; Would-Be Presidents With Cold Shoulders

results.body: Framed by two ruined houses and a dead tree, John Edwards inaugurated his 2008 presidential campaign here on Thursday with an appeal to citizens to take on challenges like the one represented by this still-devastated city. The choice of a battered New Orleans neighborhood for Mr. Edwards's unconventional announcement, with student volunteers at his
results.title: New Orleans Is Exhibit A as Edwards Opens His Presidential Campaign

results.title: The Office Pool, 2007

A similar declaration is expected shortly from Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, followed, in all probability, by Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John
results.title: Strategy, Not Drama, in Saying 'I Intend to Run in '08'

results.title: News Summary

results.title: Testing the Water, Obama Tests His Own Limits

results.title: Democrats Try Various Styles, And Pronouns

''One of the things I offer in this race is that we still remember what it
results.title: MESSAGE; A One-Time Opportunity?

results.body: THIS is the 34th annual office pool in this space, a New Year's tradition that has become the most excruciating multiple-choice prediction test in world media. Nostradamus himself couldn't score over 50 percent. Last year, despite a good bet on surging optimism in Iraq, I was mistaken 12 times out of 15. But the audacity of hope springs eternal;
results.title: OP-ED CONTRIBUTOR; The Office Pool, 2008

results.title: For New Year's Eve in Iowa, Restrained Revelry

results.title: News Summary

results.byline: By SAM ROBERTS; Diane Cardwell and Raymond Hernandez contributed reporting.

results.body: In an instant, a world in which everything seemed right suddenly seemed all wrong. John and Elizabeth Edwards's 16-year-old son, Wade, their first-born, was dead, with nothing to blame but the gust of wind that had flipped his car off a wide-open road. As the couple walked down the aisle of the church for his funeral, they braced each other,
results.title: THE LONG RUN; After the Pain of a Son's Death, A Shared Mission in Politics

results.title: THE CAUCUS; No Time to Linger in Iowa

results.byline: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JEFF ZELENY
results.title: Candidates Digging for a Deeper Pool of Iowa Voters

With the White House still occupied and the official guest
results.title: Home Sweet Hotel Suite For Obamas In the Capital

results.title: ADVERTISING; Ad Agencies Fashion Their Own Horn, and Then Toot It

Mr. Blagojevich said he would appoint Roland W. Burris, a former state attorney general who was the first
results.byline: By MONICA DAVEY; David Stout contributed reporting from Washington, and Jeff Zeleny from Chicago.

For all his accomplishments -- he was the first African-American elected to statewide office in Illinois, as comptroller and later as attorney general -- Mr. Burris, a former tax
results.title: MAN IN THE NEWS; Low-Key Groundbreaker

results.body: Word out of Hawaii is that President-elect Barack Obama has blown his cover. After three golf outings (and counting) at a private course during his extended vacation at Kailua last week, it became clear that previous portrayals of Obama as a hard-core basketball player with an occasional dalliance in golf were inaccurate. Obama, to be sworn in as
results.title: Make Room for Golf Clubs In the Oval Office

results.body: IT has been a challenging year for investors, homeowners and Republican candidates, but 2008 was very lucky for sweet caramel seasoned with fancy salt. The combination has long enchanted French and American chefs, but this year it became one of those rare flavors that works its way from an elite culinary obsession to the American mass market.
results.title: How Caramel Developed A Taste for Salt

results.body: As governor I am required to make this appointment. ROD R. BLAGOJEVICH, of Illinois, naming a successor to Barack Obama in the Senate. [A17]

results.body: After two years of army-backed emergency rule, democracy returned to Bangladesh as the secular Awami League party secured an overwhelming victory in election results announced on Tuesday. Voting on Monday had proceeded in a largely peaceful atmosphere, and in many locations it was even quite festive, according to news reports. The Associated Press
results.byline: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK; Somini Sengupta reported from New Delhi, and Julfikar Ali Manik from Dhaka, Bangladesh.
results.title: Secular Party Wins Landslide Victory in Bangladesh

Like the stories of many survivors of the earthquake that razed much of southwest China last May, the journey of Li
results.title: INSIDE THE TIMES: December 31, 2008

results.body: The Obama honeymoon here is over. When President Obama came to office, the unflattering billboards of George W. Bush, including one outside the United States Interests Section of him scowling alongside Hitler, came down and the anti-American vitriol softened. Raúl Castro, who took over from his ailing brother Fidel in 2006, even raised the
results.title: In Cuba, Hopeful Tenor Toward Obama Is Ebbing

results.body: Conservative bloggers and opinion outlets in recent days have expressed mounting alarm about an executive order by President Obama that extended certain privileges and immunities to the International Criminal Police Organization, better known as Interpol. Bloggers have accused Mr. Obama of ceding American sovereignty, painting a portrait of an
results.title: Order on Interpol Work Inside U.S. Irks Conservatives

results.body: The attempted jetliner bombing has laid bare a welter of security shortcomings. One could be easily fixed if Senator Jim DeMint would drop his wrongheaded hold and allow the Senate to confirm a new chief for the Transportation Security Administration. The Obama administration failed to offer a nominee until September, pleading the time was needed
results.title: EDITORIAL; Senator DeMint's Priorities

results.body: The National Security Agency four months ago intercepted conversations among leaders of Al Qaeda in Yemen discussing a plot to use a Nigerian man for a coming terrorist attack, but American spy agencies later failed to combine the intercepts with other information that might have disrupted last week's attempted airline bombing. The electronic
results.byline: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC LIPTON; Peter Baker in Honolulu, Adam Nossiter in Nigeria and Scott Shane in Washington contributed reporting.
results.title: U.S. SPY AGENCIES FAILED TO COLLATE CLUES ON TERROR

results.body: Wow, what a long year. Just think. At the beginning of 2009, George W. Bush was still in charge of the country, talking about how time had flown since he first ran for president. ''Just seemed like yesterday,'' he reminisced. This was a sentiment the rest of us did not entirely share. I felt as if Bush had been running things since the Mesozoic
results.title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; That Was The Year That Was

results.body: To the Editor: Re ''The System Failed'' (editorial, Dec. 30): The only positive side of the Northwest Flight 253 bombing attempt was that nobody was hurt because of the exemplary courage shown by passengers. But this incident exposes a gaping hole in the security of our national aviation system, one of the most vulnerable targets for terrorists.
results.title: LETTERS; How to Prevent Terror in the Skies

results.body: The plot to blow up a Northwest Airlines flight over American soil on Christmas Day represents an ominously new and lethal ability by a branch of Al Qaeda to attack the United States directly, according to government and independent counterterrorism specialists. Until now, American officials had expressed concern over the capability of Qaeda
results.title: Jetliner Plot Demonstrates Growing Ability of Qaeda Affiliates to Stage Attacks

results.body: A top executive at the American International Group has resigned because of salary limits imposed by the Obama administration's compensation overseer, the company said on Wednesday. Anastasia Kelly, A.I.G.'s vice chairwoman for legal, human resources, corporate affairs and corporate communications, resigned effective Wednesday for ''good reason''
results.title: A Top A.I.G. Executive Quits Over Pay Limits

results.body: An American trade panel gave final approval on Wednesday for duties of 10 to 16 percent on Chinese-made steel pipe in the biggest United States trade case to date against China. The panel, the International Trade Commission, voted 6-0 in favor of the duties set by the Commerce Department to offset Chinese government subsidies. The United States
results.title: U.S. Duties On Pipes From China Approved

results.body: In the fall of 2003, the new commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, decided on a new strategy. Known as counterinsurgency, the approach required coalition forces to work closely with Afghan leaders to stabilize entire regions, rather than simply attacking insurgent cells. But there was a major drawback, a new
results.title: History by Army Lays Out Missteps in Afghanistan

results.body: WASHINGTON -- When the Obama administration wakes up next month to a divided capital, no cabinet member will be facing a more miserable prospect of oversight hearings and subpoenas than Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. Mr. Holder is a particularly juicy target because he presides over issues that have served as recurrent fodder for political
results.title: For Attorney General, New Congress Means New Headaches

results.body: WASHINGTON -- When Robert S. Ford, a career diplomat with deep experience in the Middle East, presents his credentials as ambassador to Syria, he will be the first person to hold the job since 2005, and the public face of the Obama administration's belief in engagement over isolation. Yet few hold out much hope that Mr. Ford's arrival in Damascus
results.title: A New Ambassador to Syria, but Little Hope of Change

results.body: WASHINGTON -- With the federal government set to regulate climate-altering gases from factories and power plants for the first time, the Obama administration and the new Congress are headed for a clash that carries substantial risks for both sides. While only the first phase of regulation takes effect on Sunday, the administration is on notice that
results.byline: By JOHN M. BRODER; Matthew L. Wald contributed reporting.
results.title: Clashes Loom, With E.P.A. Set To Limit Gases

results.body: You would not lose a bet at the Caucus Room, the watering hole for power lobbyists, by wagering that the most dysfunctional agency in Washington is the Federal Election Commission. For years, far too many commission members have put their partisan loyalties far above that of the public interest. The dysfunction has now reached the point where
results.title: EDITORIAL; When Election Police Go Easy

results.body: WASHINGTON -- When the Stanford business professor Darrell Duffie co-wrote a book on how to overhaul Wall Street regulations, he did not mention that he sits on the board of Moody's, the credit rating agency. As a commentator on the economy, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former adviser to President Bill Clinton who teaches in the business school at the
results.title: Academic Economists To Consider Ethics Code

results.body: NEW DELHI -- Officials in India and Iran have been scrambling to keep the $11 billion in oil and gas trade between them going after India's central bank declared last week that a regional clearinghouse could no longer be used to settle payments for such transactions. The move, which was long sought by the United States as a way to tighten sanctions
results.byline: By LYDIA POLGREEN and HEATHER TIMMONS
results.title: India and Iran Try to Keep Energy Link Open

results.body: PALO ALTO, Calif. -- The Connecticut Huskies had been undefeated during the Obama administration, untouched by the great recession, undeterred by the fiercest obstruction from any opponent in women's college basketball. No more. Just as top-ranked UConn had feared, ninth-ranked Stanford was too big, too deep and too thorough inside and out on
results.title: STANFORD 82, UCONN 73; Streak Is Snapped at 90 As Stanford Solves UConn

results.body: WASHINGTON -- After decades of work for some of this country's most powerful lobbying firms, Lanny J. Davis, the lawyer who once helped defend President Bill Clinton from impeachment, is suddenly scrambling to defend himself. Since leaving the White House, Mr. Davis has built a client list that now includes coup supporters in Honduras, a dictator
results.byline: By GINGER THOMPSON and ERIC LIPTON; Helene Cooper contributed reporting.
results.title: Key Lobbyist's Client List Puts Him on the Defensive

results.body: 9:02 p.m. | Updated The financier Steven L. Rattner has agreed to pay $10 million to settle civil charges that he engaged in a kickback scheme involving New York state's pension fund, ending a scathingly personal and public feud between Mr. Rattner and the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. Under the settlement announced Thursday - just
results.title: Rattner Settles Pension Inquiry For $10 Million

results.body: Hypocrisy never goes out of style, but, even so, 2010 was something special. For it was the year of budget doubletalk -- the year of arsonists posing as firemen, of people railing against deficits while doing everything they could to make those deficits bigger. And I don't just mean politicians. Did you notice the U-turn many political commentators
results.title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; The New Voodoo

results.body: HONOLULU -- President Obama has long relied on his oratorical gifts to ease him through tricky political situations. But on the emotionally charged issue of gay rights, Mr. Obama has been content recently to let his lieutenants do the talking. And they have said some striking things. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton told an audience of
results.title: Obama Still Lets Surrogates Take the Lead as Gay Rights Momentum Builds

results.body: HONOLULU -- President Obama agreed on Friday to delay a request to Congress to expand the government's borrowing authority by $1.2 trillion, allowing lawmakers time to return from recess and register their views on it. The delay, which a White House official said would be only a few days, will not jeopardize the operations of the government, as
results.title: Obama Waits Before Asking For Increase In Debt Limit

results.body: International MANY OF INDIA'S POOR TURN TO PRIVATE SCHOOLS As India's economy has expanded during the past two decades, an increasing number of poor parents are now scraping together money to send their children to low-cost private schools in hopes of helping them escape poverty. results.title: Inside the Times

results.body: DES MOINES -- The attacks began three weeks ago and have not let up since: Television ad after television ad slamming Newt Gingrich for having ''more baggage than the airlines,'' for being fined by Congress for ethics violations, for his position on illegal immigration, even for admitting that he has made mistakes on the campaign trail. Democrats
results.byline: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and JIM RUTENBERG
results.title: PAC Ads Rip at Gingrich As Romney Stands Clear

results.body: Abortion The candidates all profess opposition to abortion rights, but there are distinctions. Several have signed a pledge that requires appointment only of those with anti-abortion views to key government posts. Others have declined. Some favor allowing abortion in cases of rape and incest. ''The Republican Party cannot get the issue of life
results.title: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on Key Issues

results.body: DES MOINES -- Newt Gingrich openly cried on Friday morning during an event with a group of mothers in an Iowa coffee shop as he described his own mother's illness. The Republican pollster Frank Luntz had asked Mr. Gingrich to recall a moment with his mother that changed his life. Mr. Gingrich started to describe the illness at the end of her life,
results.title: THE CAUCUS; Gingrich Weeps Recalling Late Mother's Health Struggles

results.body: It is a national disgrace that the strongest supporters of tougher mine safety concede that it will likely take another disaster before lawmakers will be willing to buck Big Coal and pass desperately needed safety legislation. ''This is out of mind until another explosion takes place,'' Representative George Miller, a California Democrat and
results.title: EDITORIAL; Big Coal's Bidding

results.body: Egypt's military council continues to demonstrate its utter contempt for the citizens who risked their lives to end President Hosni Mubarak's authoritarian rule. In the latest outrage, security forces on Thursday shut down three American-financed democracy-building groups in Cairo and as many as six other nonprofit organizations. Armed with
results.title: EDITORIAL; Egypt's Obstructionist Generals

results.body: DES MOINES -- Representative Ron Paul of Texas assailed criticism of his opposition to United States military involvement abroad, saying he fears an overreaction to worries about Iran's nuclear program could lead to war. Mr. Paul's rivals have hammered him for days as too dovish and suggested that he would do nothing to prevent Iran from acquiring
results.byline: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.; Michael D. Shear reported from Des Moines, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from Sioux Center, Iowa.
results.title: Paul Assails Rivals' Criticism of His Policy on Iran

results.body: BAGHDAD RAFE AL-ESSAWI is the man in charge of Iraq's finances, a moderate Sunni doctor who greets his guests and denounces his foes in practiced English. He may also be the next leader to fall as the country's Shiite prime minister takes aim at perceived rivals and enemies, his fate a litmus test for a country in crisis. Unlike other Sunni
results.byline: By JACK HEALY and MICHAEL R. GORDON; Jack Healy reported from Baghdad, and Michael R. Gordon from Washington.
results.title: THE SATURDAY PROFILE; A Moderate Official at Risk in a Fracturing Iraq

results.body: UNION, N.J. — Widespread gas shortages stirred fears among residents and disrupted some rescue and emergency services as the New York region struggled to return to a semblance of normalcy after being ravaged by Hurricane Sandy . Tiny increments of progress — some subway and bus lines were back in service — in the aftermath of what
results.title: Gasoline Runs Short, Adding Woes to Storm Recovery

results.body: WAUSAU, Wis. — The presidential candidates rarely trek this far north, but on election night, experts in the Wisconsin vote said, they would pay close attention to the vast region west and north of Green Bay, viewing it as a telltale of whether the state’s political upheaval since 2010 has undermined President Obama ’s bulwark of
results.title: In Wisconsin, Real Battleground Is Rural

results.body: PHILADELPHIA — First there was quiet. Then came the “ super PACs .” Now the candidate is on his way. In a striking last-minute shift, the Romney campaign has decided to invest its most precious resource — the candidate’s time — in a serious play to win Pennsylvania. Mr. Romney’s appearance here on Sunday
results.title: In Shift, Romney Campaign Makes Push in Pennsylvania

results.body: WASHINGTON — The two presidential campaigns roared back to life on Thursday, ending a storm-imposed hiatus with urgent closing arguments and a flurry of cross-country rallies as Mitt Romney raced to overtake President Obama in the election’s final 100 hours. Mr. Obama enters the last stretch with a slight and consistent — but in
results.byline: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MARK LANDLER
results.title: Storm-Imposed Intermission Over, Both Campaigns Rush Back Onto Stage

results.body: CHICAGO — Almost exactly four years ago, when President Obama was on the cusp of winning the White House, he spoke emotionally about David Axelrod , the strategist who guided him from the Illinois State Senate to the pinnacle of national politics. He praised Mr. Axelrod for his “basic take” on “how politics should be able to
results.title: Axelrod Sets More Combative Tone for Obama in 2012

results.body: To the Editor: Re “ The Upside of Opportunism ” (column, Oct. 30): David Brooks speculates that since the House Republicans would rather let the country go to ruin than allow President Obama any accomplishments, there could be no major achievements in a second term. results.title: LETTERS; Imagining a Romney Presidency

results.body: Jan. 20, 2009, was an inspiring day. Barack Obama took the oath of office and argued that America was in a crisis caused by “our collective failure to make hard choices and prepare the nation for a new age.” It was time, he said, to end the false choices between the orthodox left and the orthodox right. results.title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; The Final Reckoning

results.body: CLEVELAND — FOR one prominent Cleveland businessman, a lifelong Democrat, the election had come down to a couple of burning questions: Did he dare tell his wife that he was thinking of voting for Mitt Romney? Would she ever forgive him? In the end, although tempted, he did not dare and voted early for Obama. His quandary illustrates a
results.title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; America’s Gender Divide

results.body: If President Obama is re-elected, health care coverage will expand dramatically, taxes on the wealthy will go up and Wall Street will face tougher regulation. results.title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; The Blackmail Caucus

results.body: In a surprise announcement, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday that Hurricane Sandy had reshaped his thinking about the presidential campaign and that as a result, he was endorsing President Obama . Mr. Bloomberg, a political independent in his third term leading New York City, has been sharply critical of Mr. Obama, a Democrat, and Mitt
results.title: Bloomberg Endorses Obama, Citing Climate Change
